We compare the ML model performance of CE-FL in terms of energy consumption and delay against FedNovaÂ [41] in terms of classification accuracy obtained on Fashion-MNIST [56] and CIFAR-10 [57] datasets in Table I and II respectively (See Appendix G for the description of the datasets). FedNova is an advanced implementation of FedAvg algorithm and has been shown to outperform FedAvg udner non-uniform SGD iterations across ML data processing unitsÂ [41]. We consider time-varying datasets at the UEs, where at each global aggregation round, UEs acquire datasets with sizes distributed according to normal distribution with mean 200020002000 and variance 200200200.
We note that ML training under FedNova was performed with average CPU/data-processing frequencies, mini-batch sizes and number of SGD iterations at the DPUs.
Tables I, II demonstrate the energy and delay savings that CE-FL obtains against FedNova and AedAvg upon reaching different classification accuracies.
We observe that CE-FL outperforms FedNova, which in turn beats FedAvg, in terms of network delay and energy costs for chosen target classification accuracies on aforementioned datasets.

We first develop the centralized solver for ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\bm{\mathcal{P}} and investigate the performance of our decentralized solver against it for a network with |ğ’©|=20ğ’©20|\mathcal{N}|=20, |â„¬|=10â„¬10|\mathcal{B}|=10 and |ğ’®|=5ğ’®5|\mathcal{S}|=5. The centralized solver solves ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\bm{\mathcal{P}} via Algorithm 1 and Algorithm 2 while assuming the knowledge of all the intrinsic parameters of all the UEs, DCs and BSs used in ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\bm{\mathcal{P}}. Thus, the centralized solver performs global dual updates (94), (95) without the requirement Consensus CE-FL (Algorithm 3). The comparisons are depicted in Fig.Â 7. As can be seen from Fig.Â 7(a), our distributed solver has a comparable performance to the centralized counterpart under various consensus rounds Jâˆˆ{10,50,70}ğ½105070J\in\{10,50,70\} (see Algorithm 3); as the number of consensus rounds increases the gap between the performance of the two narrows.
We next demonstrate the performance of our distributed solver under varying network sizes while keeping number of consensus rounds J=30ğ½30J=30 in Fig.Â 7(b). We vary the number of UEs as |ğ’©|âˆˆ{10,15,20,30}ğ’©10152030|\mathcal{N}|\in\{10,15,20,30\} while fixing |â„¬|=10â„¬10|\mathcal{B}|=10 and |ğ’®|=5ğ’®5|\mathcal{S}|=5. From Fig.Â 7(b), it can be seen that increasing the size of the network indeed improves the solution of the solver due to processing larger number of datapoints across the DPUs leading to a better ML performances. However, 7(b) also highlights the shrinking gains of increasing the number of UE devices, where an initial increase in |ğ’©|=10ğ’©10|\mathcal{N}|=10 to |ğ’©|=15ğ’©15|\mathcal{N}|=15 results in significant performance enhancement; whereas, further increase in the number of UEs doesnâ€™t translate to notable improvements. This indicates that as the number of DPUs are increased beyond a certain limit, the ML performance gains are obscured by the larger cumulative network energy consumption and network delays attributed to data offloading, ML processing and aggregations.

For the purpose of our simulations, the default network consists of 20 UE devices, 10 Base Stations and 5 edge servers. Furthermore, we have used Fashion-MNIST dataset for all our proof-of-concept experiments.
